Here's an example using the existing integration test code -- https://github.com/TanYewWei/ecto/commit/694d8b3f8183d94f8415e68790c3dee2b413002a

Shouldn't the create function also return an entity with Elixir strings and lists instead of the corresponding Ecto types?

---

We should also update the README to use `:array` instead of `:list`, as well as document the handling of the Ecto.Array and Ecto.Binary types somewhere.

I think I found a bug when trying to save a decimal into a postgresql database. 
How to reproduce:
Change in the file integration_test/support/migrations.exs the decimal precision to higher value, eg:

    add :cost, :decimal, precision: 5, scale: 3

The integration tests then fails: `MIX_ENV=pg mix test`
```
  1) test primitive types (Ecto.Integration.TypeTest)
     integration_test/cases/type.exs:10
     match (=) failed
     code: [^decimal] = TestRepo.all(from(p in Post, where: p.cost() == ^decimal, select: p.cost()))
     rhs:  [#Decimal<1.00>]
     stacktrace:
       integration_test/cases/type.exs:34
```

I found this error by trying to save a small number (0.002) to postgres as a decimal. The stored value, however, was always 0.2 instead (only one decimal after the dot).

Thanks for your have an application which leverages Postgres schemas to "shard" data. There are X number of replicas contained within schemas named something like "account_1", "account_2", etc.

In Ecto 10 the ability to query on source was added by specifying `{"account_1.accounts", MyApp.Account}` in a query instead of just `MyApp.Account`. The source is annotated in any records found and it works very nicely when updating or deleting those records.

Preloading associations is a problem, however. The source tagged in the metadata of a record is not used when attempting to preload an association, so I see an error like this:

```
** (Postgrex.Error) ERROR (undefined_table): relation "relationships" does not exist
```

Where I would instead expect the relation to be "account_1.relationships".

Thank you so much for the support. Ecto is really kicking ass for us at Undead joining a multiple tables via has_many through ran into a situation where the tables are not joining correctly. The tables are referenced before they are defined in the SQL.

Example:

```elixir

defmodule Models do
  defmodule User do
    use Ecto.Model
    schema "users" do
      has_many :team_members, Models.TeamMember
      has_many :environments, through: [:team_members, :environment]
      has_many :applications, through: [:team_members, :environment, :applications]
    end
  end

  defmodule TeamMember do
    use Ecto.Model
    schema "team_members" do
      belongs_to :team_members, Models.TeamMember
      belongs_to :environments, Models.Environment
    end
  end

  defmodule Environment do
    use Ecto.Model
    schema "environments" do
      has_many :team_members, Models.TeamMember
      has_many :applications, Models.Application
    end
  end

  defmodule Application do
    use Ecto.Model
    schema "applications" do
      belongs_to :environment, Models.Environment
    end
  end
end
```

Given data is populated and tables are correctly setup.

```elixir
user = Repo.find(Models.User, 1)
Ecto.Model.assoc(user, :applications)
|> IO.inspect
|> Repo.all
```
Ecto.Query:
```
#Ecto.Query<from a in Models.Application,
 join: e in assoc(a, :environment), join: t in assoc(e, :team_members),
 where: t.user_id == ^1, distinct: [a.id], select: a>
```
SQL:
```
[debug] SELECT DISTINCT a0."id", a0."name", a0."inserted_at", a0."updated_at", a0."environment_id" FROM "applications" AS a0 INNER JOIN "environments" AS e1 ON e1."id" = t2."environment_id" INNER JOIN "team_members" AS t2 ON a0."environment_id" = e1."id" WHERE (t2."user_id" IN ($1))
```

Error:
```
(Postgrex.Error) ERROR (undefined_table): missing FROM-clause entry for table "t2"
```
